review.title: Tracking Words in Chinese Poetry of Tang and Song Dynasties with the China Biographical Database
review.abstract: Large-scale comparisons between the poetry of Tang and Song dynasties shed light on how words, collocations, and expressions were used and shared among the poets. That some words were used only in the Tang poetry and some only in the Song poetry could lead to interesting research in linguistics. That the most frequent colors are different in the Tang and Song poetry provides a trace of the changing social circumstances in the dynasties. Results of the current work link to research topics of lexicography, semantics, and social transitions. We discuss our findings and present our algorithms for efficient comparisons among the poems, which are crucial for completing billion times of comparisons within acceptable time.
histories: 9 pages, 3 figures, Workshop on Language Technology Resources and Tools for Digital Humanities (LT4DH), 26th International Conference on Computational Linguistics (COLING)

metadata.title: Tracking Words in Chinese Poetry of Tang and Song Dynasties with the China Biographical Database

sections.heading: 1 Introduction
sections.text: It is indeed the case that we are able to set out in search of new paths that we must tread in order to save the world.

sections.heading: 2 More Background Information
sections.text: Software tools for text analysis give us ample opportunity to study Chinese poetry from a variety of new positions. Comparing the poems of Li Bai (HB) 2 and Du Fu (HB), two very famous Tang poets, Jiang (2003) presented his observations from close reading, and we showed the differences of poets from the perspective of remote reading (HB et al. 2015).Researchers can focus their research on a particular aspect of CTP, e.g. Pan (2015) presented his observations on words about plants and flowers in Chinese poetry. We consider that colors represent the scenery that could be delivered by a poem; just as audio effects drive the atmosphere in a movie. The most common color in CTP is white (HB / B / 2 /). In this direction, we have some insights about the poets and cultural implications that are related to colors (HB et al. 2015, Cheng et al. 2015). In addition, we have found that female / B is most common in China.

sections.heading: 3 Linking Historical and Literary Analysis
sections.text: It is not the first time that the EU Commission has taken such a step.

sections.heading: 3.1 Social Networks among Poets
sections.text: Social Network Analysis (SNA) is proving to be an effective tool in social science studies. It is perhaps a little surprising that researchers have tried to investigate connections between poets without the help of modern computers (Wu 1993), although the results are not perfect.In CTP, a poet can mention the name of another poet in the title or in the content of a poem. It is not difficult to determine who was mentioned when the full names were used. CBDB records the alternative names of poets with which we can find further connections between poets. Often, the alternative names are short and contain only one or two characters, and it is not easy to identify the alternative names in the content of the poes.We rely on some heuristics to increase the precision of our SNA analysis.For example, we use the string of alternative names as evidence of the relationship between two poets that contain only one or two characters, and it is not easy to mention the alternative names in the content of the poems.

sections.heading: 3.2 A History of Word Occurrences
sections.text: Compiling a comprehensive Chinese dictionary is a huge, if not daunting, task. Luo (1986) led hundreds of scholars to achieve a contemporary version in 1986. We can expand the lexicon with more examples from the Tang and Song poems. Specifically, we can use information gathering techniques (Manning et al. 2008) to track how words have been used in Chinese literature over time. By using the years of birth and death of the poets recorded in the CBDB, we can draw a graph like Figure 2 to show a story about the Word4. sections.heading: 4 Locating Shared Words of Poems

sections.heading: 4.1 Comparing Individual Poems
sections.text: We design the FindCommon algorithm in Figure 3 to efficiently compare large poetry sets. To simplify our presentation, we assume that there are only two items in the CTP and only one item in the CSL, and designate a single work as a poem, temporarily ignoring whether it is a Tang poem or a song text. In the CTP, we have written the following two poems by Liu Yu-Xi ().

sections.heading: P12: 朱雀橋邊野草花，烏衣巷口夕陽斜。舊時王謝堂前燕，飛入尋常百姓家。

sections.heading: 4.2 Selecting Interesting Candidates
sections.text: We have 42,863 articles in CTP and 19,394 articles in CSL. A comprehensive comparison procedure that takes into account two points of view of a poem pair would make more than 3.8 billion comparisons in FindCommon. On a personal desktop computer with an Intel i7-4790 3.6G CPU, the Microsoft Windows 10 64-bit operating system, 32G RAM and an ordinary hard disk drive, it would take about 35 hours to complete comparisons with our Java programs. Calculation time will increase markedly if we include the Full Song Poems (as well as Lian2 Song4 shi1 /, CSP) in the comparison process. Like CTP and CSL, different sources of CSP will contain slightly different numbers of poems. There are more than 185 thousand articles in our CSP that we compare, just one point of view for all articles in CTP, CSL and CSP takes more than 30 billion comparisons and will take about 10 days to complete. We could compare the results in a single step.

sections.heading: 5 Shared Texts among Poetry of Tang and Song Dynasties
sections.text: We will discuss some interesting cases in which terms, phrases or images of Tang and Song were shared in this section (cf. Wang 2003).Although our results may lead to different types of further investigation, we will present examples roughly divided into two categories: the common words may promote certain similar or related images in poems, and the common words and expressions may indicate some questions of authorship or version of the poem.The current example we have elaborated in the previous section is a famous example of us using several terms from multiple sources in a new poem (cf. Chen & Wang 2001).In a more complete report, Zhou Ban-Yan also used a poem by Xie Tiao and a yuefu poem (cf.) 7 in p21. We have not discussed these additional poems partly because they are not part of CTP or CSL. We will summarize the results of the comparisons in Section 4 as follows.

sections.heading: Lu Yin (盧殷): 累年無的信，每夜夢邊城。袖掩千行淚，書封一尺情。(CTP)
sections.text: The following two poems in the CTP also differ in only one letter. The poets are Zhang Ba-Yuan (both letters) and Zhu Fang (both letters), two really different people, and the titles of the poems are the same. We have checked the pages of a paper version of the CTP and checked the different letters, i.e., "Zhang Ba-Yuan" / fu1 / and "Zhu Fang" / tian1 /. Therefore, we have identified a different type of author problems. Zhang Ba-Yuan: "Satisfaction," "Satisfaction," "Satisfaction," "Satisfaction," "Satisfaction," "Satisfaction," "Satisfaction," "Satisfaction," "Satisfaction," "Satisfaction," "Satisfaction," "Satisfaction," "Satisfaction," and "Satisfaction."

sections.heading: 6 Discussions and Concluding Remarks
sections.text: The meaning of words and collocations could vary from poet to poet and from dynasty to dynasty. The meaning of words and images associated with words in poetry is still very different in modern Chinese. We design FindCommon to identify and show the poetry that contained the common words and collocations, and discuss possible applications of such results. In addition to Complete Song Poem, we can and should certainly expand the current work to include a more complete history of words and collocations in Chinese poetry. The results of the current work can be improved if we can achieve high-quality word segmentation in poetry. The quality of the companies on which we perform the comparisons directly affects the observations of researchers.

sections.heading: Acknowledgements
sections.text: We thank Lik Hang Tsui, Hongsu Wang and Shuhua Zhang from the CBDB project for their informative conversations with the lead author. We also thank the anonymous reviewers for their helpful comments and suggestions. This research was supported in part by the MOST-104-2221-E-004005-MY3 scholarship from Taiwan's Ministry of Science and Technology, the USA-HAR-105-V02 scholarship from the Top University Strategic Alliance, and the Senior Fulbright Research Grants 2016-2017.

referenceMentions.context: Hu and Yu (2001) reported some analyses of unigrams and bigrams in Tang poems, and looked for Chinese synonyms in Tang and Song poems (Hu & Yu 2002).

On comparing the poems of Li Bai (李白) and Du Fu (杜甫), two very famous Tang poets, Jiang (2003) presented his observations from a close-reading viewpoint, and we showed the poets’ differences from a distant-reading standpoint (Liu et al. 2015).

On comparing the poems of Li Bai (李白) and Du Fu (杜甫), two very famous Tang poets, Jiang (2003) presented his observations from a close-reading viewpoint, and we showed the poets’ differences from a distant-reading standpoint (Liu et al. 2015). Researchers may focus their investigation on a special aspect of CTP, e.g., Pan (2015) introduced his observations about words about plants and flowers in Chinese poetry.
Specifically, we apply techniques of information retrieval (Manning et al. 2008) to track how words were used in Chinese literature over time.

That some words were used only in the Tang poetry and some only in the Song poetry could lead to interesting research in linguistics. That the most frequent colors are different in the Tang and Song poetry provides a trace of the changing social circumstances in the dynasties. Results of the current work link to research topics of lexicography, semantics, and social transitions. We discuss our findings and present our algorithms for efficient comparisons among the poems, which are crucial for completing billion times of comparisons within acceptable time.
